As a middle school teacher in a poverty-stricken area of Los Angeles for the last thirteen years, I am very happy to see this column. Every day my colleagues and I see the results of poor prenatal care in our twelve-year-old students, and it is heartbreaking.

It is also frustrating, anger-provoking, and is one of the most stressful things about trying to teach. This column is the reality. All the other stuff about Common Core, "critical thinking", and the achievement gap is a sideshow. Until the children of poverty are taken care of in infancy, they will be behind on the basics for their entire public school career, without even being able to access the higher levels of education.

It is indeed "infuriating" that a program like the Nurse-Family Partnership is not better funded. So the question becomes, why isn't it better-funded? Good governing is not just about finding more resources (i.e., raising taxes) but about making the right choices. WuDunn and Kristof mention redeploying money from high school and college into these programs but the debate should not end there. Is this program more effective than universal pre-K? Is it more effective than race to the top education funds? How about housing subsidies? Expanded medical care? If this program is in fact as effective as the authors say it is, then, in the absence of new funds, federal, state and local governments should be examining ALL their social programs with an eye to finding the money to fund it.

Airline miles and the numerous rebates and prizes that are offered by a variety of national merchants, are little more than commercial bribery for which the recipients pay no income tax and the cost is often passed on to corporate shareholders and the consumer. The problem is compounded when those who seek such rewards actually look for the highest prices and longest trips, rather than seek to get the best value for the money of those who actually pay the cost.

In the end, the personal effort to win points impacts all of us adversely, except those who get major rewards. It is a kind of ponzi scheme that benefits only a relatively small group of executives of companies that make the awards and a relatively small group, at the high end, of those who get the rewards. The rest who get rewards are are fooled into think they have scored. In fact, they are just less burdened by the process than the rest of us, who get little if anything.

The IRS and the anti-inflation people ought go on the warpath over those schemes.
